Simulated Annealing

Originally written: June 5, 2020

Sometimes, a probÂ­lem doesn't have a known, efÂ­ï¬Â­cient, deÂ­terÂ­minÂ­isÂ­tic alÂ­goÂ­rithm. This hicÂ­cup isn't necÂ­esÂ­sarÂ­ily a big deal beÂ­cause ofÂ­ten we only care about getÂ­ting an anÂ­swer that is close enough. One alÂ­goÂ­rithm that can give apÂ­proxÂ­iÂ­mate valÂ­ues for hard to solve probÂ­lems is simÂ­uÂ­lated anÂ­nealÂ­ing. Before jumpÂ­ing into the R code, let's look at a moÂ­tiÂ­vatÂ­ing exÂ­amÂ­ple.

Motivation

The travÂ­elÂ­ing salesÂ­man probÂ­lem doesn't have a polyÂ­noÂ­mial-time deÂ­terÂ­minÂ­isÂ­tic alÂ­goÂ­rithm and thus is a good canÂ­diÂ­date for us to exÂ­plore. The probÂ­lem name itÂ­self nearly gives away the deÂ­tails. Imagine a map with some ï¬xed numÂ­ber of ranÂ­domly placed cities. We now want to hire a salesÂ­perÂ­sonâ€”let's name her Sallyâ€”who needs to visit every city, withÂ­out reÂ­visÂ­itÂ­ing any city, to sell some prodÂ­uct.

When the numÂ­ber of cities is small, we can use brute force techÂ­niques to try every posÂ­siÂ­ble perÂ­muÂ­taÂ­tion of city orÂ­derÂ­ings. Of course, for a relÂ­aÂ­tively large amount of cities, tryÂ­ing to ï¬nd the route this way will be inÂ­tractable. We aren't comÂ­pletely doomed though. Do we care if Sally takes the most opÂ­tiÂ­mal route? For this sitÂ­uÂ­aÂ­tion, not reÂ­ally. While we want Sally to take a fast route, it doesn't have to be the fastest route. Luckily, it turns out that simÂ­uÂ­lated anÂ­nealÂ­ing can tractably genÂ­erÂ­ate fast routes.

How does it work?

The travÂ­elÂ­ing salesÂ­man probÂ­lem is a litÂ­tle comÂ­pliÂ­cated, so let's set up a toy probÂ­lem inÂ­stead. For this demonÂ­straÂ­tion, we are goÂ­ing to ï¬nd the global minÂ­iÂ­mum of the sine funcÂ­tion for the doÂ­main [0, 2Ï€]. For the mathÂ­eÂ­matÂ­iÂ­cally inÂ­clined, you could use techÂ­niques from calÂ­cuÂ­lus class to ï¬nd that the anÂ­swer is -1. Thus, if our alÂ­goÂ­rithm's anÂ­swer is not in the same ballÂ­park as -1, then we know someÂ­thing went wrong.

State Spaces

Simulated anÂ­nealÂ­ing searches through a state space itÂ­erÂ­aÂ­tively. An itÂ­erÂ­aÂ­tive alÂ­goÂ­rithm beÂ­gins with an iniÂ­tial guess. This guess is then poÂ­tenÂ­tially upÂ­graded every itÂ­erÂ­aÂ­tion of the alÂ­goÂ­rithm to proÂ­duce a betÂ­ter apÂ­proxÂ­iÂ­maÂ­tion. For our demonÂ­straÂ­tion, we'll end the alÂ­goÂ­rithm afÂ­ter a ï¬xed numÂ­ber of itÂ­erÂ­aÂ­tions.

Taking care of the iniÂ­tial guess is easyâ€“just choose a ranÂ­dom valid state. From the iniÂ­tial guess, we'll need to ï¬nd it's neighÂ­borÂ­ing states and check to see if they're betÂ­ter. Disappointingly, there is no sinÂ­gle method to deÂ­rive neighÂ­borÂ­ing states. We'll have to come up with a method speÂ­ciï¬c to our probÂ­lem.

Here, I want to keep things simÂ­ple. The imÂ­pleÂ­menÂ­taÂ­tion beÂ­low adds a ranÂ­dom numÂ­ber from the range [-0.1, 0.1] to the curÂ­rent state to genÂ­erÂ­ate the sucÂ­cesÂ­sor. I also wrap the new state value around if it exÂ­ceeds the range [0, 2Ï€].

Of course, you can exÂ­perÂ­iÂ­ment on your own. For exÂ­amÂ­ple, try thinkÂ­ing of new ways to genÂ­erÂ­ate neighÂ­borÂ­ing states.

Temperature Schedule Go Brrr

This temÂ­perÂ­aÂ­ture idea is what gives simÂ­uÂ­lated anÂ­nealÂ­ing its name. The temÂ­perÂ­aÂ­ture value of the alÂ­goÂ­rithm is analÂ­oÂ­gous to the role of temÂ­perÂ­aÂ­ture when anÂ­nealÂ­ing metal. To anÂ­neal metal, the metal is ï¬rst heated and then slowly cooled over time. This coolÂ­ing process alÂ­lows the metal to have imÂ­proved ducÂ­tilÂ­ity and reÂ­duced britÂ­tleÂ­ness. By enÂ­durÂ­ing a long coolÂ­ing peÂ­riod, the metal is imÂ­proved. Similarly, the rate at which the â€œheatâ€ of the alÂ­goÂ­rithm is deÂ­creased deÂ­terÂ­mines the acÂ­cuÂ­racy of the apÂ­proxÂ­iÂ­maÂ­tion.

The â€œheatâ€ of the alÂ­goÂ­rithm afÂ­fects the probÂ­aÂ­bilÂ­ity that it will make a bad move on purÂ­pose. Surprisingly, the alÂ­goÂ­rithm someÂ­times needs to make bad moves to reach the global opÂ­tiÂ­mum. Why? There is a chance that it might get stuck on a loÂ­cal opÂ­tiÂ­mum. By makÂ­ing bad moves, the alÂ­goÂ­rithm can poÂ­tenÂ­tially stumÂ­ble its way out of loÂ­cal opÂ­tiÂ­mum (but this isn't guarÂ­anÂ­teed).

You can choose any numÂ­ber to be the iniÂ­tial temÂ­perÂ­aÂ­ture. The temÂ­perÂ­aÂ­ture schedÂ­ule then deÂ­terÂ­mines how the temÂ­perÂ­aÂ­ture value will deÂ­crease every itÂ­erÂ­aÂ­tion. Like choosÂ­ing neighÂ­borÂ­ing states, there is no right way to deÂ­crease the temÂ­perÂ­aÂ­ture. The only rule of thumb is that the slower the temÂ­perÂ­aÂ­ture is dropped, the betÂ­ter the apÂ­proxÂ­iÂ­maÂ­tion will be. The tradeÂ­off is that you'll have to wait longer to get an anÂ­swer. Thus, choose someÂ­thing that short enough for your atÂ­tenÂ­tion span and long enough to get a good anÂ­swer.

For our toy exÂ­amÂ­ple, I choose to subÂ­tract an arÂ­biÂ­trary numÂ­ber every itÂ­erÂ­aÂ­tion.

Once again, feel free to get creÂ­ative and try difÂ­ferÂ­ent iniÂ­tial valÂ­ues and schedÂ­ules for your imÂ­pleÂ­menÂ­taÂ­tion.

Probabilistically Making Moves

Every itÂ­erÂ­aÂ­tion a neighÂ­borÂ­ing state is genÂ­erÂ­ated. The alÂ­goÂ­rithm will alÂ­ways reÂ­place the curÂ­rent state with the new state if it's betÂ­ter. As we just disÂ­cussed, the new state may be worseâ€“dragÂ­ging us furÂ­ther away from an opÂ­tiÂ­mum. Yet, we want to ranÂ­domly make some bad moves with some probÂ­aÂ­bilÂ­ity. The key to simÂ­uÂ­lated anÂ­nealÂ­ing is that this probÂ­aÂ­bilÂ­ity is not conÂ­stant. Rather, it on avÂ­erÂ­age deÂ­creases over time.

The probÂ­aÂ­bilÂ­ity of choosÂ­ing the new state is deÂ­ï¬ned as the folÂ­lowÂ­ing forÂ­mula:

$$\exp(\frac{\bigtriangleup E}{T})$$

Two paÂ­raÂ­meÂ­ters afÂ­fect the probÂ­aÂ­bilÂ­ity The â€œchange in Eâ€ paÂ­raÂ­meÂ­ter is the difÂ­ferÂ­ence beÂ­tween the funcÂ­tion apÂ­plied with the poÂ­tenÂ­tial new state and the funcÂ­tion apÂ­plied with the curÂ­rent state. The bigÂ­ger this difÂ­ferÂ­ence, the smaller the probÂ­aÂ­bilÂ­ity. The next paÂ­raÂ­meÂ­ter is the temÂ­perÂ­aÂ­ture value, which we've alÂ­ready seen. Obviously, for every itÂ­erÂ­aÂ­tion of the alÂ­goÂ­rithm, the temÂ­perÂ­aÂ­ture value will deÂ­creaseâ€“causÂ­ing the probÂ­aÂ­bilÂ­ity to deÂ­crease slowly.

As the temÂ­perÂ­aÂ­ture gets closer to zero, the probÂ­aÂ­bilÂ­ity of choosÂ­ing a bad move will also get closer to zero. Towards the end, the alÂ­goÂ­rithm will mostly take greedy moves toÂ­wards betÂ­ter states. Once the temÂ­perÂ­aÂ­ture hits zero, then the alÂ­goÂ­rithm is done. We can get our anÂ­swer and go home.

Put Everything Together

We've covÂ­ered all the imÂ­porÂ­tant parts of this alÂ­goÂ­rithm. Let's put everyÂ­thing toÂ­gether and see it in acÂ­tion. Here is the full code for my soÂ­luÂ­tion.

I deÂ­cided to capÂ­ture the state for every itÂ­erÂ­aÂ­tion and graph the reÂ­sult. As you can see, the iniÂ­tial state is nowhere near -1. As the alÂ­goÂ­rithm proÂ­gresses, it beÂ­gins to slowly conÂ­verge. Towards the end, the probÂ­aÂ­bilÂ­ity of choosÂ­ing bad moves is near 0, which is why the downÂ­ward slope for later itÂ­erÂ­aÂ­tions is steep.

For this run, I got a ï¬Â­nal state of 4.703329. The corÂ­reÂ­spondÂ­ing sine value is -0.9999590, which is close to -1. These two valÂ­ues match what we exÂ­pected.
